clinical_study.brief_title: Effectiveness and Safety of Mobile Artificial Cervical Vertebrae Replacement for Patients With Cervical Spondylosis
clinical_study.official_title: Effectiveness and Safety of Mobile Artificial Cervical Vertebrae Replacement for Patients With Cervical Spondylosis: Study Protocol for a Prospective, Non-randomized Controlled, Clinical Trial

collaborator.agency: Second Affiliated Hospital of Xi'an Jiaotong University

brief_summary.textblock: The research team designed an artificial cervical joint prosthesis suitable for subtotal resection of the lower cervical vertebral body. Previous studies regarding cadaver and animal experiments have found that this artificial joint not only retains the normal range of physiological motion of the joint, but also has good stability. Preliminary studies have shown that the designed joints are sufficiently safe and stable. The titanium materials for joints have been verified for their toxicology in long-term clinical trials and have been monitored under relevant national testing agencies in China.

detailed_description.textblock:
Artificial cervical disc technology has achieved certain clinical effects in the treatment of single-segment lesions of the lower cervical spine. However, simple artificial cervical disc replacement is only applicable for single-segment disc herniation, but not for two adjacent cervical segmental lesions, concurrent with vertebral hyperplasia and ossification of the posterior longitudinal ligament in the cervical spine. Traditional vertebral corpectomy and bone graft fusion can reduce the mobility of the cervical spine. Therefore, non-fusion fixation for such diseases has been a key issue to improve the efficacy of surgical treatments.
To this end, the research team designed an artificial cervical joint prosthesis suitable for subtotal resection of the lower cervical vertebral body. Previous studies regarding cadaver and animal experiments have found that this artificial joint not only retains the normal range of physiological motion of the joint, but also has good stability. Preliminary studies have shown that the designed joints are sufficiently safe and stable. The titanium materials for joints have been verified for their toxicology in long-term clinical trials and have been monitored under relevant national testing agencies in China.
To serve clinical patients faster and ensure that the trial design is safe, this study is designed to observe the effectiveness and safety of mobile artificial cervical vertebrae replacement for patients with cervical spondylosis.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: Participants are assigned to one of two or more groups in parallel for the duration of the study
study_design_info.masking_description: Nonrandomized Trial: participants are expressly assigned to intervention groups through a non-random method, such as physician choice

primary_outcome.measure: Cervical joint range of motion at 6 months after operation
primary_outcome.description: Testing methods for cervical joint mobility include: Cervical joint range of motion in all directions will be accurately obtained through an in vitro infrared measurement after artificial joint replacement (joint range in °).

secondary_outcome.measure: Cervical fusion rate at 3 to 6 months after operation
secondary_outcome.description: A successful fusion is assessed according to Brantigan and Steffee's imaging rating scale: Suspicious bone fusion: bone bridge formation in the entire fusion area with a density at least similar to postoperative data, and no light-transmitting band between the grafted bone and the vertebral body; Strong fusion: the fused bone in the fusion area is more mature and dense as shown on postoperative images. A sclerosis zone between the grafted bone and the vertebral body indicates the fusion, but there is no interface between the grafted bone and the vertebral body, and the mature bone trabecula forms a bone bridge. The bone spurs on the anterior side of the vertebral body will be absorbed, and the bone graft in the intervertebral space will move forward until the facet joints are fused. Fusion rate = (number of successfully fused patients/total number of patients) × 100% (Fusion rate in percentage).

secondary_outcome.measure: Cervical joint range of motion at 7 days to 3 months after operation
Japanese Orthopaedic Association (JOA) scores at 7 days to 6 months after operation
secondary_outcome.description: JOA scoring involves upper limb motor function (4 points), lower limb motor function (4 points), sensation (6 points) and bladder function (3 points). The higher score indicates the better motor function

secondary_outcome.measure: Neck Disability Index (NDI) scores at 7 days to 6 months after operation
secondary_outcome.description: NDI is mainly used for assessing cervical spine function. The higher score indicates the severer cervical spine dysfunction.

secondary_outcome.measure: Visual analogue scale (VAS) scores at 7 days to 6 months after operation
secondary_outcome.description: VAS is mainly used for pain assessment. The higher score indicate the severer pain.

secondary_outcome.measure: CT images of the cervical spine at 7 days postoperatively
secondary_outcome.description: CT images of the cervical spine are used to evaluate the implantation of the artificial cervical joint.

secondary_outcome.measure: X-ray of the cervical spine at 7 days to 6 months after operation
secondary_outcome.description: X-ray of the cervical spine is used for evaluating the morphology of the implanted cervical joint morphology.

other_outcome.measure: The incidence of adverse events at 7 days to 6 months after operation.
other_outcome.description: Adverse events include implant shedding, displacement, joint loosening, fracture, prolapse, infection, and heterotopic ossification. The incidence of adverse events = (number of patients with adverse events/total number of patients)×100%.

arm_group.description: 20 patients with cervical spondylosis undergoing mobile artificial cervical vertebrae replacement
20 patients with cervical spondylosis undergoing anterior cervical corpectomy and fusion

intervention.description: Position: The patient is in a supine position with the neck hyperextended, ensuring his/her neck and shoulders in a stable and neutral position before surgery and the cervical spine in a "physiological" curvature position. Anesthesia: General anesthesia via oral tracheal intubation. Surgical approach: Anterior cervical spine approach through the space between the visceral sheath and the vascular sheath. Surgical method: Two intervertebral discs with adjacent lesions and part of the vertebral body between them will be removed. A curette is used to carefully strike off the annulus fibrosus and cartilage on the surface of the adjacent upper and lower endplates. Intraoperatively, the midlines of the segment and the vertebra to be replaced should be mapped out. When decompression, the midline for decompression should not be deviated from the planned midlines.

Position: The patient is in a supine position with the neck hyperextended. Anesthesia: General anesthesia via oral tracheal intubation. Surgical approach: Anterior cervical spine approach through the space between the visceral sheath and the vascular sheath. Surgical method: Two intervertebral discs with adjacent lesions and part of the vertebrae between them will be removed. A curette will be used to carefully strike off the annulus fibrosus and cartilage on the surface of the adjacent upper and lower endplates. The removed vertebral bone will be trimmed into cancellous bone particles and filled in a cervical titanium cage with an appropriate size. The titanium cage will be implanted into the vertebral space, and fixed with adjacent vertebrae using anterior cervical titanium plates and screws.
